title: City finance boss is caught on film hiding planning notice from Chelsea neighbours
title_page: City finance boss is caught on film hiding planning notice from Chelsea neighbours | Daily Mail Online
text:
This is the moment a City finance boss was caught on camera hiding a planning notice from his neighbours in a bitter row over his new basement.
Gregory Hutt was granted permission to build the family room and lounge beneath his £6million home in Chelsea in 2014, but a ban was imposed on the use of power tools without written approval from council planners.
Now, his next door neighbours Jonathan and Robyn Tan say they have filmed Mr Hutt turning around a planning notice giving details of how people living in the area could challenge his appeal to lift the restrictions.
Dirty tricks: City finance boss Gregory Hutt was caught on camera flipping round a planning notice from his neighbours in a bitter row over his new basement beneath his £6million home in Chelsea
Mr Hutt (right) was granted permission to build the family room and lounge beneath his £6million home in Chelsea (left) in 2014, but a ban was imposed on the use of power tools without approval from council planners
Dentist Mr Tan says the noise and dust from the proposed building work could lead him to having to shut his surgery.
He and his wife have spent the last two years fighting the plans, while his patients have raised concerns over the upheaval, and the potential effect the work - and the resulting dust - could have on hygiene.
The notices were put up on November 25, and Mr Tan says he has seen Mr Hutt turn around the sign on several occasions, as the businessman was headed to his job as chief financial officer of specialist financial services firm Pershing.
'We'd turn it back so people could see it, but when he came back from work in the evening he'd turn it back again,' Mr Tan told the Evening Standard.
'My wife tried to attach some wire to stop him. It was ridiculous, so we thought, "Let's catch him in the act".'
Now, his next door neighbours Jonathan and Robyn Tan (pictured) say they have filmed Mr Hutt turning around a planning notice giving details of how people living in the area could challenge his appeal to lift the restrictions
The notices were put up on November 25, and Mr Tan says he has seen Mr Hutt turn around the sign on several occasions, as the businessman was headed to his job as chief financial officer at the firm Pershing
Sneaky: Mrs Tan filmed Mr Hutt spin the sign around so that it faced the road, instead of the pavement (shown)
Dismissive: Mr Hutt said: 'That [the video] is too trivial to discuss. This is not a mega-basement. We don't understand why people are upset by the plans'
After waiting by a window with her phone, Mrs Tan filmed Mr Hutt spin the sign around so that it faced the road, instead of the pavement.
They then posted the footage on Facebook and it was later shown to a meeting of planning chiefs at the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
However, Mr Hutt won his fight for the restrictions to be lifted, on the proviso that the work complies with a report by environmental consultants and following the implementation of a plan to manage traffic during the excavations.
